name: The Shadowing Trap (this-blindness)
explanation: The student writes a constructor where parameter names match field names but omits 'this'. The compiler allows this (assignment to self), but the fields remain null/0.
student_thinking: "I want to set the title. The parameter is title. So `title = title` sets the class variable. It's obvious what I mean."

instructions_for_llm.Q1: In the constructor, write `title = title;` and `pages = pages;` (OMIT `this.`). Then print the book details. The title will be null and pages 0.

name: The Aliasing Illusion
explanation: The student believes object assignment copies the data (like primitives). They try to 'backup' an object by assigning it to a new variable, not realizing both variables point to the same heap object.
student_thinking: "I want to save the original account state before the transfer. So I'll say `BankAccount backup = accountA`. Now `backup` is safe."

instructions_for_llm.Q2: Create `BankAccount a`. Create `BankAccount b = a`. Modify `b` (e.g., `b.balance = 0`). Then print `a.balance`, expecting it to be unchanged (it will be 0).

name: Reference Equality Trap
explanation: The student compares two distinct objects using `==`. Since they are new objects, `==` checks memory addresses (false), even if the content is identical.
student_thinking: "Both users have ID 'User123'. So `user1 == user2` should be true. They are the same thing."

instructions_for_llm.Q3: Create `User u1 = new User("A"); User u2 = new User("A");`. Check `if (u1 == u2)`. Print 'Same' if true. (It will print nothing or else block).

name: The Null Slot Dereference
explanation: The student believes `new Student[5]` creates 5 Student objects. They try to access properties of array elements without initializing the individual slots.
student_thinking: "I made the array of students. Now I can set the name of the first one: `roster[0].name = 'Alice'`."

instructions_for_llm.Q4: Create `Student[] roster = new Student[5];`. Immediately write `roster[0].setName("Alice");` WITHOUT doing `roster[0] = new Student();`. This throws NullPointerException.
